Award.AwardTitle: The Emergence of Human Complex Abilities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research concerns early human culture and the implications of early bone tools for assessing human cognitive abilities. Worked bone tools are considered among the important features characterizing modern human behavior. In Europe complex bone technologies are characteristics of the Upper Paleolithic which began about 40,000 years ago. Bone tools were made with techniques specifically adapted to bone materials such as scraping, grinding and polishing and a wide range of shapes and functions (split-base points, bone handles, spear-throwers, points, harpoons). The bone technology of earlier "pre-modern" humans is said to be simpler and involving a lower degree of conceptualization than Upper Paleolithic tools. Limb bones used as hammers and scrapers for the manufacture of stone tools are known from European sites as old as 500, 000 years ago. Just a few pieces show evidence of shaping by flaking and fully shaped tools are even rarer. The goal of this research is to understand in greater detail the processes by which they were made. This research will not only further basic knowledge regarding the human past but also further international scientific collaboration. The research involves close collaboration by members of an international team.

Multiple tools made by flaking elephant long bones of symmetrical shape have been described in four sites in Latium (Italy) dated between 400,000 and 300,000 years ago. The manufacturing technique used was the same technique used in knapping stone artifacts. This transfer of techniques from stones to bone is taken as an indication that pre-modern humans were incapable of creative thinking. An important aspect of early bone technology is about the criteria used to correctly identify tools since various natural processes can produce mimics of man-made tools. This project will carry out a technological and taphonomic analysis of all the bone and stone tools from the assemblage of Castel di Guido dated to about 400,000 years ago. Many pieces classed as tools present only a limited amount of modification that is not distinctive enough to remove doubts about their intentionality. Analysis will be directed to the elimination of ambiguities in the identification of flaked bone artifacts by using features characteristic of stone artifacts. The fact that recent advances in dating suggest that the four sites in Latium are closer in time than expected invite a question: do these occurrences of flaked bone artifacts so common in the Latium region represent a genuine regional tradition, reflecting a set of socially transmitted habits between groups in the same region? This would run counter to the conventional idea that pre-modern culture was static and homogeneous over its large geographic extent and long periods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Archaeologists distinguish bone tools made by percussion flaking, i.e. the same techniques used in knapping stone artifacts, and so-called ?formal? bone tools made with techniques specifically conceived for bone and ivory materials, such as splitting, scraping, grinding and polishing. Formal bone tools are common in the Upper Paleolithic and are considered as one of the important features characterizing modern human behavior. The traditional assumption is that early hominids and Neandertals were only capable of producing a few, simple bone tools based on percussion flaking or using bone hammers for retouching stone artifacts. Only very few examples of formal tools are known from two sites in France dated toward the end of the Neandertal period, about 50,000 to 40,000 years ago.

The major goal of this project was to investigate this traditional belief by doing a systematic analysis of all the bone and stone tools from the Middle Pleistocene assemblage of Castel di Guido, an open-air site in central Italy, excavated between 1980 and 1991, with an imprecise date between 327,000 and 260,000 years ago. Its bone assemblage, with tools made by flaking elephant long bones, is known from a monograph published  by  Radmilli and Boschian  in 1996 yet it is still poorly known for a number of reasons. 

Many of the drawings are incorrect, a few are definitely wrong and the artifact state  of preservation or natural damage are overlooked. According to the monograph there are 373 bone tools including 99 bifaces (= handaxes). These are overestimates of true bone tools by inclusion of pieces with a doubtful amount of man-made modifications. Some researchers (Gary Haynes ) expressed skepticism  regarding the interpretation of bone tools at Castel di Guido as true artifacts. He argued that what was needed were systematic technological analyses with explicit descriptions of features that define human action as opposed to natural agencies. In this project we used features characteristic of stone artifacts to identify pieces that were deliberately flaked and separate them from bones that are the incidental byproduct of marrow extraction or too abraded for a diagnosis.

All bone artifacts received an index of confidence using the following categories:

  • 0 = unmodified or too abraded for a diagnosis;
  • 1 = possible tool but no sufficient evidence such as unpatterned removals (due to natural damage) or removals too abraded;
  • 2 = good evidence of intentionally flaked artifact;
  • 3 = clear evidence supported by a combination of attributes.

We consider true tools only pieces with index of confidence 2 or 3.

 

The most significant results of our research project are:

  • Sebastien Nomade and Alison Pereira have dated the site by the 40Ar/39Ar method to ca. 400,000 years ago, much older than previous age estimates of 260,000 to 327,000 years. Samples collected at the site during the original excavation were provided by G. Boschian.
  • In spite of the fact that the number of bifaces had been largely overestimated, the number of verified, human-made bone tools is 98.  This is the highest number of flaked bone tools from any Lower or Middle Paleolithic published to date.
  • The bone assemblage is characterized by a clear diversity of tool types and the systematic use of diaphysis fragments as tool blanks. In this respect the CDG bone tools are neither expedient nor occasional.
  • Smoothers, a type of bone tool with a rounded, polished and flattened tip, are a common Upper Paleolithic ?mainly Aurignacian- tool interpreted as tools for smoothing dry hides. One of these tools is present at CdG and another at the German site of Sch?ningen (now dated to about 300,000 years ago). These pieces and others, like the intermediate pieces prove that the innovative technology of the Aurignacian have roots that go back to the Lower Paleolithic.
